column2: This PR is created to enhance audit api response with collector item optional fields, collectively called as auditEntity in response.

column2: Hi, so over the last few weeks I have been working on setting up a Hygieia Dashboard. I have been able to successfully install all the collectors and see a really cool dashboard. I did find a problem with the hygieia-jenkins plugin though. When you specify the buildStatus on the pipeline syntax for hygieiaBuildPublishStep it does not filter out builds that do not meet the criteria. Additionally I could not find where in mongodb did the buildStatus information get stored. If someone has any idea how to find any information on this or knows the fix, please help. Thank you.
column5: Hygieia-Jenkins Plugin hygieiaBuildPublishStep Broken

column2:
When using the GitHub configuration widget and editing an existing configuration if I do not re-enter the 'Personal Access Token', the system will re-encrypt the Token leading to Access Denied errors when the GitHub collector runs..

This raises a related question.  Why is the Personal Access Token sent back to the user's browser?  It is not being de-encrypted and in this UI mode, can't really be used for anything.  It is resulting in errors being produced when editing the form if one is not fully aware of the underlying UI processing mechanism.  There are other issues I see, that if interested we can discuss off line.
column5: Github Widget

column2:
Fix #2972 by moving metric strings and version numbers out of properties file and into collector
  the Config from admin page overrides any config from properties file
Fix #2971 by supporting multiple usernames and passwords for multiple sonar instances
column5: Fix/sonar multiple servers

column2:
I have multiple sonar qube instances (for historical reasons). If I make a modification to the configuration through the UI the records get reordered in the database. However in the properties file there are version numbers and REST query URLs that are hardcoded to a certain array index...

Obviously this causes problems. Should be fetching the version from the sonar instance. and the metric string can just be part of the client class.
column5: SonarQube properties and UI config conflict with each other
SonarQube collector does not support multiple servers with multiple accounts

column2: I think my answer might be related to #2549, but is there some way I can configure a widget in the team dashboard to either show the output from two or more sources, or add more than one of a kind of widget?

column2:
Looks like Sonar has set a max page size of 500 on api/projects as well now. Experimenting out our Sonar system with 1333 projects, nothing is returned from the collector beyond the first page. Can we add paging support to have the collector loop through all pages increment the pageIndex until all records are collected? 

Related to: https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/issues/933
column5: Sonar Collector: Unable to pull in projects beyond the first page (500 records)

I am working on enhancing the rally collector to capture defect/Testcase data along with all existing information. Looking for help or any pointer to start.

@Satheesh-Balachandran - I believe you have last worked on the rally collector, is there anything you can help me with,

Below are the end points which gives the required information for Defects/Testcases.

Number of Open Defects for a Project - `https://rally1.rallydev.com/slm/webservice/v2.0/defect?project=https://rally1.rallydev.com/slm/webservice/v2.0/project/<Project-id>&query=(state="open")`

Number of TestCases - `https://rally1.rallydev.com/slm/webservice/v2.0/testcase?project=https://rally1.rallydev.com/slm/webservice/v2.0/project/81341151288`

column2:
Hello,
I recently started a Hygieia Dashboard by running the ui and api as docker containers. I want to integrate Jenkins into Hygieia and cannot find any instructions on how to do so, especially for docker. I did find instructions for integration if the dash was deployed not through docker but nothing for docker container deployment.
Thank you in advance.
column5: Integrate Jenkins into Hygieia Dash (Setup using Docker)

column2:
I was playing with the artifactory artifact collector docker container and I noticed that the properties-builder.sh for it produced a property file with out of date syntax. ([this](https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/blob/master/collectors/artifact/artifactory/docker/properties-builder.sh#L41-L51) and [this](https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/blob/master/collectors/artifact/artifactory/docker/properties-builder.sh#L81-L103) vs [what the docs say](https://hygieia.github.io/Hygieia/artifactory.html#sample-application-properties-file))

In looking at some of the un-merged PRs I noticed one where the api and api-audit container Dockerfiles were being re-written with mounted directory for the properties file (#2767). Is that a refactor that all the containers will eventually hit? Or does the properties-builder.sh for artifactory just need some updating?

Thanks!
column5: Question about state of Docker containers (Artifactory properties-builder)

column2:
I have created a new Jira cloud trial account. In the hygieia documentation username:password(encoded in base64) is mentioned for collector authentication. I am trying to authorize Jira with collector using email:password(encoded in base64) format but it's not working.  

I searched on the internet and found that Jira has already removed username field from Jira.

https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/blog/2018/06/say-goodbye-to-usernames-in-atlassian-cloud?_ga=2.159559613.184535873.1559202112-814553513.1559113992.

I tried to hit the API using postman with email:password and also bypassing basic auth key in header. but it's not working there also.


I am not sure with the issue, But I have a prod instance of Jira, Where older user can able to login using username:password but new users are getting 401.
column5: Jira Collector Username Authorization issue

column5: Help with Artifactory

column2:
@tabladrum @Sbrenthughes @nireeshT @satishc1 
I was using Hygieia v3.0.1 and had issues trying to get the Bitbucket collector from pulling commit history from a private repository. I did follow all the documentation. My dashboard consisted of Monitor (green - which showed that it was able to connect to my Bitbucket instance) and repo which was failing to collect the commits. The Bitbucket log showed that the request was returning a 401. When I tried to curl the same API using my Personal Access Token, I successfully got back all the commits. This could only mean that something was fiddling with my Personal Access Token that led to me getting a 401. I then stumbled upon the issue https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/pull/2919 which suggests that the Personal Access Token is getting decrypted which is wrong. I have now freshly cloned the latest Hygieia repository and when I tried to build it, it failed. 

_**Note:** I have not re-built hygieia-core as I had built it earlier before building Hygieia v3.0.1_

column2:
- Refactors DefaultBambooClient to execute Bamboo API calls in parallel batches
- Speeds up fetches for ~5k plans from 2 hours to <10 minutes (depending on network / server)
- Adds BambooAsyncFetch.java
- Parallel batch size configurable (default: 10)
column5: Feat/bamboo fast fetch

column2:
I found this in issue https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/issues/1929

> make sure token has full privileges to access data of version one and check application.properties file url of version one.

I have **project lead** privileges in versionOne. with this I was able to retrieve kanban results but no scrum results. 

**Kanban results** 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7926653/57879793-1d4e0280-77d2-11e9-8de8-316f16c9f135.png)

**No scrum results**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7926653/57880388-78ccc000-77d3-11e9-9f87-72114c975500.png)


I checked the logs for any issues I only this 
This is what I see when the collector starts
```
2019-05-08 20:57:49,668 INFO  o.s.c.c.c.ConfigServicePropertySourceLocator - Fetching config from server at: http://localhost:8888
2019-05-08 20:57:49,902 WARN  o.s.c.c.c.ConfigServicePropertySourceLocator - Could not locate PropertySource: I/O error on GET request for "http://localhost:8888/application/default": Connection refused (Connection refused); nested exception is java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused (Connection refused)
2019-05-08 20:57:49,904 INFO  com.capitalone.dashboard.Application - No profiles are active
2019-05-08 20:57:49,939 INFO  o.s.c.a.AnnotationConfigApplicationContext - Refreshing org.springframework.context.annotation.AnnotationConfigApplicationContext@119acf47: startup date [Wed May 08 20:57:49 UTC 2019]; parent: org.springframework.context.annotation.AnnotationConfigApplicationContext@c19732f
```

2019-05-16 19:01:09,787 INFO  c.c.d.collector.FeatureCollectorTask - Feature Data Collection Finished
```

Here's my application.properties file 
```
dbname=dashboarddb
dbusername=hygieia
dbpassword=hygieiapassword
dbhost=localhost
dbport=27017
dbreplicaset=false
dbhostport=localhost:27017
logging.file=./logs/versionone.log
feature.pageSize=2000
feature.deltaStartDate=2016-03-01T00:00:00.000000
feature.masterStartDate=2016-03-01T00:00:00.000000
feature.deltaCollectorItemStartDate=2016-03-01T00:00:00.000000
feature.cron=0 * * * * *
feature.versionOneBaseUri=https://versionone-url/
feature.versionOneAccessToken=MYTOKEN
feature.sprintEndPrior=7
feature.epicQuery=epicinfo
feature.memberQuery=memberinfo
feature.sprintQuery=sprintinfo
feature.queryFolder=v1api-queries
feature.storyQuery=story
feature.projectQuery=projectinfo
feature.teamQuery=teaminfo
feature.trendingQuery=trendinginfo
```

column2:
Hey guys,

I've been setting up Hygieia for a while, and I've got a weird behavior on Product Dashboard. I've four widgets working properly. They're:
Code Repo: Bitbucket Collector
Build: Jenkins-Build Collector
Code Analysis: SonarQube and Jenkins-Cucumber Collectors
Deploy: Hygieia Publisher Plugin

My problem is on Product Dashboard. The dashboard is showing up the commit blocks, and I can see the commits moving from one environment to the other. However, I'm stuck in a problem.

Let's say that I've one commit sitting in DEV stage and one commit sitting in QA stage. Each commit represents a different version of my app (I've double checked on database, and they're different). If I run the deployPublisher to deploy into STG, both commits move to STG rather than only the commit sitting on QA (again, same application but different versions).

Btw, my flow is COMMIT -> BUILD -> DEV -> QA -> STG -> PRD

Am I missing something here?
column5: Commit transition - Product Dashboard

column2:
Problem: When attempting to rehome to a new MongoDB, it fails to authenticate. Sniffer capture shows it is not using the `admin` DB in Mongo to authenticate, rather it is trying to auth against the DB where Hygieia will be storing its data.

Relevant log excerpt:
```
[{address=REDACTED:27021, type=UNKNOWN, state=CONNECTING, exception={com.mongodb.MongoSecurityException: Exception authenticating MongoCredential{mechanism=SCRAM-SHA-1, userName='REDACTED', source='REDACTED_DB_NAME', password=<hidden>, mechanismProperties={}}}, caused by {com.mongodb.MongoCommandException: Command failed with error 18: 'Authentication failed.' on server REDACTED:27021. The full response is { "ok" : 0.0, "errmsg" : "Authentication failed.", "code" : 18, "codeName" : "AuthenticationFailed", 
```

... where `REDACTED_DB_NAME` is the name of the DB that Hygieia will store its data, should it be able to auth... which is the same DB I see in the sniffer caps it is trying to perform initial auth to, instead of `admin`.

I have connected to the same Mongo cluster with the same creds - though using the `admin` DB to auth, of course - and it works fine.

I did try changing some of the Spring Boot config relevant to this (e.g.: `spring.data.mongodb.authentication-database=admin`), but no joy.

Is there something I'm missing here, or is the code hardwired to assume that the user lives in Hygieia's DB, instead of `admin`?
column5: Unable to get services to auth against "admin" DB in Mongo; uses Hygieia's DB, instead

	at com.capitalone.dashboard.collector.NexusIQCollectorTask.collect(NexusIQCollectorTask.java:29) ~[nexus-iq-collector-3.0.2-SNAPSHOT.jar!/:3.0.2-SNAPSHOT]
	at com.capitalone.dashboard.collector.CollectorTask.run(CollectorTask.java:63) ~[core-3.0.4.jar!/:3.0.2-SNAPSHOT]
	at org.springframework.scheduling.support.DelegatingErrorHandlingRunnable.run(DelegatingErrorHandlingRunnable.java:54) ~[spring-context-4.2.5.RELEASE.jar!/:4.2.5.RELEASE]
	at org.springframework.scheduling.concurrent.ReschedulingRunnable.run(ReschedulingRunnable.java:81) [spring-context-4.2.5.RELEASE.jar!/:4.2.5.RELEASE]
	at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:511) [na:1.8.0_201]
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266) [na:1.8.0_201]
	at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.access$201(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:180) [na:1.8.0_201]
	at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.run(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:293) [na:1.8.0_201]
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1149) [na:1.8.0_201]
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:624) [na:1.8.0_201]
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748) [na:1.8.0_201]
```

It looks to me like it is getting a NullPointer when trying to read the username, but I am including it in the config file:

```
# Database Name
dbname=dashboarddb

# Database HostName - default is localhost
dbhost=my.db.ip.address

# Database Port - default is 27017
dbport=27017

# Database Username - default is blank
dbusername=dashboarduser

# Database Password - default is blank
dbpassword=dbpassword

# Collector schedule (required)
nexusiq.cron=0 0/5 * * * *

# Nexus IQ server(s) (required) - Can provide multiple
nexusiq.servers[0]=https://my.nexus.iq.url

# Nexus IQ username/password - with read-access to all reports, and so on.
nexusiq.username=myUsername
nexusiq.password=myPassword

logging.level.com.capitalone.dashboard.collector=DEBUG

#In case of multiple license violations for a given library, consider the strictest violation
nexusiq.selectStricterLicense=true
```

(I have replaced my urls, credentials, ips, etc. with placeholder values).

It looks like it is finding my properties file, as my NexusIQ url is correctly loaded, but it does not seem to be able to find the username for some reason. Am I configuring something incorrectly, or is there an issue with how the properties file is loaded in the collector?
column5: Nexus IQ Collector: NullPointerException Getting Username

column2:
So, I have been asked to evaluate Hygieia for use with our stack and right away I suspect the Bitbucket cloud connector only supports API v1. I say this based on documentation that refers to the `v1/api`
As well as looking at [The actual code](https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/search?q=DefaultBitbucketCloudClient&unscoped_q=DefaultBitbucketCloudClient)

The whole reason this is an issue is because [bitbucket is discontinuing the 1.0 endpoint in April](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/bitbucket/deprecation-notice-v1-apis/) and it's significantly different than 2.0 - I know this because I just got done with a lot of integration straddling between them

Also, not directly related but important: BB is deprecating API tokens in favor of OAUTH

https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/bitbucket/bitbucket-api-changes-gdpr/

**My issue:** Am I correct in my assumptions about V2 support for BB?
column5: BB Connector support for BB API 2.0

column2:
This PR allows the UI to be served from the [Red Hat Software Collections nginx images](https://github.com/sclorg/nginx-container).  These images are not intended to run as a specified UID and as such do not have access to places like `/etc/nginx/conf.d`.

`substitute-nginx-proxy-pass.sh` is placed in `./nginx-start/` at build time to correctly set the API server hostname

`api.conf` is a `proxy_pass` snippet that is placed in `./nginx-default-cfg/` for proper routing to the API server

It is intended to be used in an openshift buildconfig such as:

```yaml
- apiVersion: v1                                                                                                                                                                              
  kind: BuildConfig                                                                                                                                                                           
  metadata:                                                                                                                                                                                   
    creationTimestamp: null                                                                                                                                                                   
    labels:                                                                                                                                                                                   
      app: ${COMPONENT}                                                                                                                                                                       
    name: ${COMPONENT}                                                                                                                                                                        
  spec:                                                                                                                                                                                       
    nodeSelector: null                                                                                                                                                                        
    output:                                                                                                                                                                                   
      to:                                                                                                                                                                                     
        kind: ImageStreamTag                                                                                                                                                                  
        name: ${COMPONENT}:latest                                                                                                                                                             
    postCommit: {}                                                                                                                                                                            
    resources: {}                                                                                                                                                                             
    runPolicy: Serial                                                                                                                                                                         
    source:                                                                                                                                                                                   
      images:                                                                                                                                                                                 
      - as: null                                                                                                                                                                              
        from:                                                                                                                                                                                 
          kind: ImageStreamTag                                                                                                                                                                
          name: build-${COMPONENT}:latest                                                                                                                                                     
        paths:                                                                                                                                                                                
        - destinationDir: .                                                                                                                                                                   
          sourcePath: /opt/app-root/src/dist/.                                                                                                                                                
        - destinationDir: ./nginx-default-cfg                                                                                                                                                 
          sourcePath: /opt/app-root/src/docker/rhel/api.conf                                                                                                                                       
        - destinationDir: ./nginx-start                                                                                                                                                       
          sourcePath: /opt/app-root/src/docker/rhel/substitute-nginx-proxy-pass.sh                                                                                                                 
      type: Image                                                                                                                                                                             
    strategy:                                                                                                                                                                                 
      sourceStrategy:                                                                                                                                                                         
        from:                                                                                                                                                                                 
          kind: ImageStreamTag                                                                                                                                                                
          name: nginx:latest                                                                                                                                                                  
          namespace: openshift                                                                                                                                                                
      type: Source                     
```

1. APM (Dynatrace)

As we continue our journey towards continuous delivery we realized that if we can have the performance test results published to Hygieia it will help the teams to review the quality and performance of the code in a single place.

Different teams use different APM solutions out of which the prominent names are Appdynamics, Dynatrace etc. Our use case is dynatrace. Is there any plan to make a widget that will be available on the dashboard to which we can integrate dynatrace results (Performance Test). Is this a capability that is already available ?

2. LogSearch (Splunk)

Is there any plan for Splunk integration to the Hygieia dashboard ? This would be for the feedback on application during a functional/regression or performance test or even after an artifact deployment. The widget in this integration if can check a predefined set of queries on Splunk and upload the results that would be helpful.

Looking forward for the feedback on these queries.
column5: Application performance management & Log Search Integration with Hygieia for Continuous feedback

column2:
Have been tracking down the source of a frustrating issue where Jenkins build collector doesn't seem to respect settings from configuration.

Commented out these lines from the `properties-builder.sh` and it resolved the issue

```
if [ "$TEST_SCRIPT" != "" ]
then
        #for testing locally
        PROP_FILE=application.properties
else
	PROP_FILE=config/hygieia-jenkins-build-collector.properties
fi
```

It would seem this would allow for the properties file to be created in the wrong location. Where the config would be written to `config/hygieia-jenkins-build-collector.properties` but the application will be started with 

```
--spring.config.location=$PROP_FILE
```
Where `$PROP_FILE` is provided by the Dockerfile as `ENV PROP_FILE /hygieia/config/application.properties`
column5: Inconsistencies in docker property-builder script causing unexpected failure due to misconfiguration

column2:

Create a team dashboard with build,deploy, repo widgets
View widget view and ensure data is displayed properly in all widgets
Switch to pipeline view and click on save (not required to add environments)
Switch back to widget view and one widget is (usually build widget) in a not-configured state
Switch to pipeline view and click on configure, save (Save is a must, if you just switch between views this won't happen)
Switch back to widget view, another widget will be in a not-configured state
If you do it several times all widgets will go to not-configured state one by one

column2:
As part of the Hygieia planning session at Verizon this past summer, SingleStone committed to working on a few new features. This one relates to simplifying the initial setup of Hygieia.
 
**Problem:** 
The initial installation and configuration of Hygieia is time consuming and requires many steps and tools to be installed (e.g. Java, Maven, Node, gulp, Mongo, etc.). From personal experience this can take 1-3 hours depending on the installers familiarity with all the tools listed above. Based on a discussion with @tabladrum, this is one of the largest sources of issues from the Hygieia community and solving this issue would result in less support issues being generated.
 
**Outcomes:** 
A new user can get Hygieia up and running in less than 10 minutes (from initial download to dashboard created and being populated with real data).
 
**Design Thoughts:**
1. Reasonable defaults should be used so streamlined installation can support ~100 teams or dashboards out of the box with minimal/no configuration. More sophisticated highly available and fault-tolerant installations are beyond the initial scope.
1. When Hygieia is “run” this means the UI, API and the default set of collectors required to populate the default dashboard are automatically started from a single command. 
1. Ideally the user can configure which collectors are started in a simple way and/or the can shutoff previously started collectors quickly.
1. The approach should be cloud-native, but support on premise / local installations too.

**Design Options:**
**Docker Hub** - A publicly available image containing all the software necessary to run Hygieia pre-installed. Users would install with “docker pull hygieia” and run with “docker run hygieia”. This image would include all the current “capitalone/hygieia-*” repos currently published on [hub.docker.com](hub.docker.com) (basically the UI, API and reasonable default set of collectors in a single image).

**AWS ECS & EKS** - Similar to above, this would enable a user with an AWS account to launch Hygieia in a managed environment. To launch, the user would choose the Hygieia image, create a task definition, configure the service and cluster before launching. 

**Hygieia AMI** - A baked AMI published to the AWS Marketplace with all Hygieia components installed that is used to stand-up a new instance. Once a user logs into their AWS account, from the marketplace, they specify the Action Type, EC2 instance size, VPC, Subnet, Security Group and Key Pair then clicks Launch to start the server.

**Next Steps**
This issues is meant to start a discussion in this community on how to proceed forward. Before writing code, we want to tease out other requirements, ideas and options on how this might be done before implementing it (likely starting in December).
column5: Streamline Hygieia Onboarding

column2:
Hi, 

I am trying to implement multiple same type widgets on a single dashboard. For example, having multiple GitLab repositories or multiple Jenkins builds in the same dashboard. 

Looking at the MongoDB and Java classes, I can see that each dashboard contains an application,  which contains an array of components.  A component then contains a map of CollectorType:ListOfCollectorItem, meaning that in theory, it can contain multiple Gitlab repos or Jenkins builds. Now it looks as if the current implementation should in theory allow multiple same type widgets, but that is not the case. I can see two ways of doing this. For example, let's say we want two GitLab repositories on the same dashboard: 

1) A dashboard contains an application, and this application contains two components. 
      Component A: has GitLab repo 1
      Component B: has GitLab repo 2
2) A dashboard contains an application, the application contains one component.
     Component A: has two GitLab repos 

Since I can't really wrap my head around this, could you explain why currently multiple same type widgets are not supported, and what is the limitation? Just FYI, I am not a front-end guy, so I haven't investigated the UI that much, maybe the limitation is on that side?

Thanks
column5: Multiple same type widgets on the same dashboard - what is the limitation?

column2:
These changes are for a gamification dashboard that encourages competition between teams by comparing them based on a set of metrics.

**Configuring Hygieia for the Dashboard**
The administrator must make an API call to the new `/gamification/metrics` endpoint to initialize the metrics in the database. The endpoint is documented in Swagger. Once the metrics have been initialized, the administrator can toggle metrics and set the score ranges in the administration page.

**Configuring the Dashboard**
To populate the dashboard, the user creates a product dashboard with at least one team. Assuming the administrator has performed the configuration mentioned above, a gamification tab will appear at the top of the product dashboard page. 

**Accessing the Dashboard**
When the user clicks on the gamification tab at the top of their product dashboard, they will be presented with a bar graph and a table showing the scores for each team.
column5: Gamification Dashboard

column2: New functionality keeps getting added to collectors, such as the Github collector retrieving issues, comments, and pull requests. However these changes don't get applied to the other collectors such as gitlab and subversion.  Because of this, all the SCM collectors have different functionality.  What would you think about adding another abstract class, or an interface that all collectors of a type would have to extend/implement.  For example, for the SCM collectors, they could extend a new ScmCollectorTask, which would have methods you have to implement for collecting commits, issues, etc... We could create these for all the different types as well.  That way when new functionality is added, it will force all the collectors to stay in sync. In cases such as subversion where there is no concept of "issues", it would just be a "noop" for the implementation of that method.  It will also provide a consistent structure for creating new collectors.
column5: Out of sync collectors

column2: Started to implement a v2 of the rest API.  Before we started to do the entire thing, we wanted to get a small piece out there to get some feedback on, so we rewrote the "Dashboards" controller.  We followed what we had mentioned in #1444 , and implemented v2 using Spring's hateoas library.  You will notice upon making a get request to "/api/v2/", the response will contain links to resources in the application.  Right now there are only a couple relating to dashboards, but eventually there will be more as more controllers are added.  Making a get request to the dashboards endpoint will give you the list of dashboards, and each of the dashboards will have a link to itself.  We also updated swagger to separate v1 from v2, so you can see the different versions of the api.  We tried to avoid making changes to the backend services as much as possible, but there were a couple small changes that had to be made to make this work properly, but nothing that breaks backwards compatibility.
column5: Rest API v2

column2:
With more and more properties being added, it's getting very difficult to manage all the properties in a clean way.  We have come across multiple issues with docker properties builders, and the complexity will only get worse as more are added.  There is also an issue with redundancy, as can be seen with the mongo settings that are repeated for all the collectors, as well as the API.  @Mpluya had opened a pull request #1138 to utilize spring cloud config, which would definitely reduce the amount of redundant properties.  It could also remove the need for the docker properties builders which has a lot of complexity in the scripts.  We have been talking about this, and our ideal state would be below.

Phase 1:
Add the dependency for spring cloud config.  We could add the codebase for a spring cloud config server to Hygieia's codebase, as seen in #1138 , or we could have that outside the project all together.  We could then let the cloud config server manage all the properties, and have those loaded on startup.  

Phase 2:
Begin to shift properties from the cloud config server to an admin page on Hygieia's UI.  The end state would ideally be the cloud config server having the mongo properties, and then each collector could get the other properties from the database after connection.  This would allow you to modify things like jenkins servers, or gitlab host from the UI, instead of properties files.  This would not need to be done all at once, and could potentially be moved over in parts.  This would remove the need for the properties builder, and potentially the need for dockerfiles altogether through use of docker maven plugin configuration. 

Would appreciate some feedback and your thoughts.  
@brennanananan @Mpluya @tabladrum @amitmawkin @satishc1 @nireeshT @MarkRx
column5: State of configuration properties

column2:
Wanted to throw out some ideas to get opinions.

## Current Implementation, user "admin" always admin:
### Description:
"Standard" user with username "admin" will always get admin privileges, so first person to create that account gets admin.
### Pros:
- Always an admin
### Cons:
- First person to create account gets admin
- Can't ever take away the admin users admin privileges
- Have to have Standard Authentication enabled to add other admins
- Solution is very hacky

## Alternate 1, first account created admin:
### Description:
The first user added to the UserInfo collection would get the admin role.
### Pros:
- Easy to enable
- Works for both Ldap or Standard
### Cons:
- If users already exist, no admin account will be created

## Alternate 2, admin account created by app on app startup if not existing
### Description:
When the application starts up, will check to see if an admin account exists, if there isn't one, one would be created.
### Pros:
- Would guarantee an admin account exists
- Works even if users already exist
### Cons:
- Would have to display admin account credentials in logs or something
- Would have to have standard login enabled

## Alternate 3, admin user account in application properties
### Description:
We could add new properties to the application properties for creating an admin account if it's not already there.
### Pros:
- Works even if users already exist
- Can always add new admins
### Cons:
- Admin account credentials in a props file
- Requires standard login enabled

## Alternate 4, next login if no admins is admin account
### Description:
If no admin accounts exist, the next account to login would get the admin role.
### Pros:
- Guarantees admin account
- Works for standard or ldap
### Cons:
- Have to check to see if admins exist on every login
- Race to see who logs in first after change made
column5: First Admin

column2:
This is a proposal for a new "Multi-team" dashboard that acts as a normal team dashboard with N number of components. It could be implemented two ways - (1) as simply an aggregation of existing team dashboards, or (2) as a fully configurable dashboard with each dropdown/selection allowing multiple collector items.

I have had a number of requests for a dashboard view that reports on multiple components at once. The goal would be to show all of the data normally found on a team dashboard in an aggregated way. For example:
- The feature widget would be able to include multiple teams / projects at once.
- The code repo widget would show multiple lines in the graph (one for each repo) with statistics on max and average commit counts
- The build widget would show multiple lines in the graph (one for each job). Average build duration could show histograms for each day. Latest builds could be over all jobs.
- The quality widget would show statistics on all components. Some, like the code coverage metric, could use percentiles (10th, 25th, 50th,
 75th, 90th) represented in some graphical form to best show data from multiple components.
- The monitor widget could allow for logical groupings of monitors
- The deploy widget would show a union of all of the unique environments. When entering the detailed view all of the components would be shown in a list.

The pipeline widget would show all of the components (#1259)

The goal is to better support highly componentized applications (such as by use of micro-services) while still being able to show the data in a single view intended to be consumed by developers. The product dashboard doesn't quite fit this use case because it is more of a "metrics" dashboard. Furthermore it's quite difficult to get set up (look at all the github issues raised by it) and has a number of issues.
column5: Proposal: Multi-team dashboard

As a power user of Hygieia
I want to have the ability to support rollups and weighted averages
So that I can visualize high level metrics composed of a collective of lower level metrics.

In the case of no weight specified the default behavior would be to assign a weight equally for the average.

Examples:
Production Defects: display the total number of defects for a product aggregated from features that make up the product
Performance Metrics: display performance as a higher level metric that is a weighted average of throughput, latency, and response times
column5: Ability to Use an Aggregator

column2:
I have read the code to calculate the average time of code commit in each pipeline stage.
![average time](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15209842/24744685/7493817e-1ae5-11e7-8f86-e7eef3a063b7.png)
The code is between line 114 and 182 in js file UI\src\components\widgets\product\js\commit-data.js.
For example, in order to calculate the average time of Commit stage, it will calculate the time intervals of  Commit stage -> Prod stage, Commit stage-> QA stage, Commit stage -> DEV stage, Commit stage-> BUILD stage, and it will calculate the time intervals of all the code commit time to now in Commit pipeline stage, then calculate the average of all the time intervals, is this reasonable？ why?

Another issue, I think when calculate the average time of each pipeline stage, the order of all the stages should be Commit, Build, DEV, QA, Prod, but when I debug the code, the order is Build, Commit ~~~, the first one should be Commit not Build. 
![order](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15209842/24745541/a1e20c7e-1ae8-11e7-9160-ae34c13fbf2b.png)
column5: The average time of commit in each pipeline stage in product level dashboard make people puzzled.

column2: With the amount of potential tools available to integrate with Hygieia, it will probably be very difficult to manage at some point.  Have you guys given any thought to creating some sort of plugin architecture for Hygieia for adding new tools.  For instance, instead of having Gitlab, Github, SVN and Bitbucket available by default as SCM collectors, don't have any available until you "install" the plugin for the tool, however that may look.  I know it would be a significant effort, but it might be worth thinking about with all the potential tools available for integration.

column2:
![latest_build](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15209842/23534178/0e7a9990-fff1-11e6-8aa0-ec7ac7e715c5.png)
After a new build info has been imported to hygieia server, the build stage will make a request, such as http://localhost:3000/api/build/?componentId=58aba84b22b4042344b9ac6c&endDateBegins=1488258758706&endDateEnds=1488357136355, to update the latest build number. If the time of jenkins server is earlier than hygieia server, the endTime of the new build info should be earlier than endDateBegins which always use the current time of hygieia server, so the request will never get any info, the latest build number can't be updated.
In order to avoid this issue, I suggest using the endTime of the new build info as the endDateBegins.
column5: The latest build number in the pipeline build stage can't be updated.

column2: If an older version of a component is deployed it will not be reflected properly in the product dashboard. This is because the EnvironmentComponentEventListener always adds the commits from the builds from the latest artifacts. There is no logic to remove commits. Thus if an older version is deployed into an environment newer commits will still exist in the pipeline document resulting in an inaccurate dashboard.
column5: Deploying old applications does not properly reflect in the product dashboard

column2: When a build is marked as unstable by Jenkins, Hygieia marks this change set (collection of GitHub commits) as a failure (red). The next successful running of this job should mark these as successful (green) and move the change set forward in Hygieia. However, Hygieia does not handle this properly and instead will keep the change set from an unstable build in the commit stage for as long as this data persists. Furthermore, an unstable build should show as a yellow status in Hygieia, providing more clarity to the user as requested in this issue: [https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/issues/84](https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/issues/84)
column5: Hygieia unable to handle unstable Jenkins builds

column2:
When using the GitHub configuration widget and editing an existing configuration if I do not re-enter the 'Personal Access Token', the system will re-encrypt the Token leading to Access Denied errors when the GitHub collector runs..

This raises a related question.  Why is the Personal Access Token sent back to the user's browser?  It is not being de-encrypted and in this UI mode, can't really be used for anything.  It is resulting in errors being produced when editing the form if one is not fully aware of the underlying UI processing mechanism.  There are other issues I see, that if interested we can discuss off line.

column2:
Looks like Sonar has set a max page size of 500 on api/projects as well now. Experimenting out our Sonar system with 1333 projects, nothing is returned from the collector beyond the first page. Can we add paging support to have the collector loop through all pages increment the pageIndex until all records are collected? 

Related to: https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/issues/933

Hello everyone,

I'm very new to DevOps and want to learn how to incorporate collectors like Sonarqube and Fortify into Hygieia using an EC2 image that contains Docker.

I've already found a few sonar examples such as the one here https://github.com/docker-library/docs/tree/master/sonarqube, but I am having trouble since my portainer image already uses port 9000. I'm not sure what to change the port to in the 
$ docker run -d --name sonarqube -p 9000:9000 sonarqube
command.

Right now, I don't have anything from Sonarqube or Fortify to pull in, but I am trying to be ready because that will be my next step.

Thank you very much!

column2:
On the first execution of the Jenkins collector there is a NPE that prevents the collector document for Jenkins from being created. This prevents the General Configuration page from showing the Jenkins configuration.

NPE is avoided by initializing the offending fields in the HudsonSettings class.
column5: Fix NPE breaking admin page config

column2:
I was playing with the artifactory artifact collector docker container and I noticed that the properties-builder.sh for it produced a property file with out of date syntax. ([this](https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/blob/master/collectors/artifact/artifactory/docker/properties-builder.sh#L41-L51) and [this](https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/blob/master/collectors/artifact/artifactory/docker/properties-builder.sh#L81-L103) vs [what the docs say](https://hygieia.github.io/Hygieia/artifactory.html#sample-application-properties-file))

In looking at some of the un-merged PRs I noticed one where the api and api-audit container Dockerfiles were being re-written with mounted directory for the properties file (#2767). Is that a refactor that all the containers will eventually hit? Or does the properties-builder.sh for artifactory just need some updating?

Thanks!

server.contextPath=/api
server.port=8081
logRequest=true
corsEnabled=true
corsWhitelist=http://<IP_ADDRESS>:3000
```
gulpfile.js file content
```
    config = {
        module: 'hygieia-dashboard',
        local: null,
        api: 'http://<IP_ADDRESS>:8081',
        refresh: 60
    };
```
When I click on login button, I get ✅ meaning API connectivity is working properly.
When I try to signup for new user, I get *User already exist* issue. However the actual issue is related to CORS. Here is the screenshot -
![Screen Shot 2019-05-31 at 1 27 01 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7900526/58734828-5e870a80-83ad-11e9-9c57-2d95166d2b12.png)
Even if I have added proper whitelisting for CORS configuration */api/registerUser* is not setting proper header *Access-Control-Allow-Origin*
Following are the two screenshots which might help

1. Initial */registerUser* request with OPTIONS
![Screen Shot 2019-05-31 at 1 34 09 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7900526/58734950-ca697300-83ad-11e9-8fc0-ec3c01bd20dc.png)
2. Second */registerUser* request with POST
![Screen Shot 2019-05-31 at 1 33 18 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7900526/58735005-f553c700-83ad-11e9-8023-209c9c4c771d.png)


This issue is similar to #1710 
/cc @juantoledo @nireeshT @stevegal @jshpopelka272 @tabladrum

Thanks in advance
column5: CORS issue when api port other than 8080

column2:
I have created a new Jira cloud trial account. In the hygieia documentation username:password(encoded in base64) is mentioned for collector authentication. I am trying to authorize Jira with collector using email:password(encoded in base64) format but it's not working.  

I searched on the internet and found that Jira has already removed username field from Jira.

https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/blog/2018/06/say-goodbye-to-usernames-in-atlassian-cloud?_ga=2.159559613.184535873.1559202112-814553513.1559113992.

I tried to hit the API using postman with email:password and also bypassing basic auth key in header. but it's not working there also.


I am not sure with the issue, But I have a prod instance of Jira, Where older user can able to login using username:password but new users are getting 401.
column5: Jira Collector Username Authorization issue

column2:
Hi Team,
i am doing a POC by deploying hygieia in 

[api.txt](https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/files/3236885/api.txt)

kubernetes cluster in google cloud.
in brief,i have cloned the master branch and built API/UI and imported mongo db image from open source and created the dashboard db.

here are the list of issues i have encountered :
1) UI is not getting connected to API
2) i am not getting any response from API while using below url : 
a) http://api-service:8080/api/appinfo 
b) http://api-service:8080/api/swagger/index.html
c)  http://api-service:8080/ping --> this works
ran these commands from both inside the container as well as from the service which was exposed to outside 
errors : 
vishal_devops_2019@gke-test-default-pool-6cbf8333-bp45 ~ $ docker exec -ti e6143272df5d        sh
# curl http://localhost:8080/api/swagger/index.html                     
{"timestamp":1559216908570,"status":404,"error":"Not Found","message":"No message available","path":"/api/swagger/index.html"}# 
# curl http://localhost:3000/api/swagger/index.html
curl: (7) Failed to connect to localhost port 3000: Connection refused
# netstat -ntlp
Active Internet connections (only servers)
Proto Recv-Q Send-Q Local Address           Foreign Address         State       PID/Program name    
tcp6       0      0 :::8080                 :::*                    LISTEN      8/java              
# curl http://localhost:8080/ping
true# 
# curl http://localhost:8080/api/appinfo
{"timestamp":1559217242537,"status":404,"error":"Not Found","message":"No message available","path":"/api/appinfo"}# 

after deploying UI and exposing the service, i am not able to move further as the API connectivity is not happening and the inspect logs are pointing to the UI ip.
i have changed the default and conf-builder file by mapping the api service name but still iyt's not working.

can anyone please provide the solution. attached the API & UI logs
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16570454/58631586-abf96e00-8300-11e9-9d04-dfc80fcc4644.png)


[UI.txt](https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/files/3236886/UI.txt)
Regards,
vishal

column5: Help with Artifactory

column2:
Hygieia allows any unauthenticated user to view the dashboard list without login first.
We want only authenticated users to view any data on hygieia dashboards otherwise users should be redirected to login page first.
column5: Hygieia dashboard view for only authenticated users

column2: Look up tries to use the collectorItemId which causes a null pointer when enabling the score widget and configuring the Feature widget. Updated to look up by the collectorId.
column5: Fixes: #2929

column2:
address issue #2908 

This stems from when I moved to the visitor pattern to pick up the test results instead of specifying the result type on the UI. I left the boilerplate code for `testResultType` in the Step.
column5: remove unused `testResultType` from collector. Fixes issue #2908

column2: Currently the external API for the github-graphql collector is generated wrong.

column2:
@tabladrum @Sbrenthughes @nireeshT @satishc1 
I was using Hygieia v3.0.1 and had issues trying to get the Bitbucket collector from pulling commit history from a private repository. I did follow all the documentation. My dashboard consisted of Monitor (green - which showed that it was able to connect to my Bitbucket instance) and repo which was failing to collect the commits. The Bitbucket log showed that the request was returning a 401. When I tried to curl the same API using my Personal Access Token, I successfully got back all the commits. This could only mean that something was fiddling with my Personal Access Token that led to me getting a 401. I then stumbled upon the issue https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/pull/2919 which suggests that the Personal Access Token is getting decrypted which is wrong. I have now freshly cloned the latest Hygieia repository and when I tried to build it, it failed. 

_**Note:** I have not re-built hygieia-core as I had built it earlier before building Hygieia v3.0.1_

column2:
I am trying to include HygieiaTestPublisStep in my pipeline and when generating pipeline syntax from jenkins I am seeing the below error

``no public field ‘testResultType’ (or getter method) found in class jenkins.plugins.hygieia.workflow.HygieiaTestPublishStep``

Attaching the screenshot for reference. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19859827/58122331-0727b400-7bcf-11e9-8fb4-f09398edf437.png)

column5: Are xml files supported in HygieiaTestPublishStep?

Hi Team,

I am trying to up UI, API, DB and Jenkins Build Collector in docker-compose setup.

I have cloned the hygiea repositories and executed maven commands for building the required jar files.

Then modified the docker.compose.yml file like below.
version: '3'
services:
  db:
    image: mongo:latest
    ports:
      - "27017:27017"
    volumes:
      - "db-data:/data/db"

  db-setup:
    build: db
    depends_on:
      - db

  api:
    build: api
    image: hygieia-api
    depends_on:
      - db-setup
    ports:
      - "8080:8080"

  ui:
    build: UI
    image: hygieia-ui
    depends_on:
      - api
    ports:
      - "3000:80"

  jenkins-build-collector:
    build: collectors/build/jenkins
    image: hygieia-jenkins-build-collector
    depends_on:
      - db-setup

volumes:
  db-data:
  certs:

And modified the docker-compose.override.yml
version: '3'
services:
  api:
     # environment: # for a full list check the corresponding properties-builder file
     #   - DB_DATABASE: dashboarddb
     #   - DB_HOST: db
     #   - DB_PORT: 27017
     #   - DB_USERNAME: dashboarduser
     #   - DB_PASSWORD: dbpassword
     # volumes:
     #   - ./logs:/hygieia/logs

  ui:
    # environment:

  jenkins-build-collector:
    environment:
    - JENKINS_CRON=2 * * * * *
    - JENKINS_MASTER=http://my-jenkins-server
    - JENKINS_USERNAME=<api-user>

Error:
The build collector is not getting up and throws error as MONGO_PORT not defined.

- Refactors DefaultBambooClient to execute Bamboo API calls in parallel batches

column2:
Hey guys,

I've been setting up Hygieia for a while, and I've got a weird behavior on Product Dashboard. I've four widgets working properly. They're:
Code Repo: Bitbucket Collector
Build: Jenkins-Build Collector
Code Analysis: SonarQube and Jenkins-Cucumber Collectors
Deploy: Hygieia Publisher Plugin

My problem is on Product Dashboard. The dashboard is showing up the commit blocks, and I can see the commits moving from one environment to the other. However, I'm stuck in a problem.

Let's say that I've one commit sitting in DEV stage and one commit sitting in QA stage. Each commit represents a different version of my app (I've double checked on database, and they're different). If I run the deployPublisher to deploy into STG, both commits move to STG rather than only the commit sitting on QA (again, same application but different versions).

Btw, my flow is COMMIT -> BUILD -> DEV -> QA -> STG -> PRD

Am I missing something here?
column5: Commit transition - Product Dashboard

column2:
Removes the requirement for the properties to use:
```
feature.jiraStoryIds[0]=
feature.jiraEpicId=
```

Now the collector only relies on `feature.jiraIssueTypeNames=` to have the issue type names in a comma separated string as usual.

column2:
Problem:

Currently the Jira collector forces the user to make a manual API call to look up the Issuetype Ids and then insert them into the properties file. Ideally the collector should handle this.

Solution:
Update the Jira collector to auto populate the issue type ids using the API `https://[your-jira-domain-name]/rest/api/2/issuetype`
column5: Jira Collector Needs to Auto Populate Issue IDs

feature.jiraOauthRefreshtoken=

feature.jiraOauthExpiretime=


#############################################################################
# In Jira, general IssueType IDs are associated to various "issue"
# attributes. However, there is one attribute which this collector's
# queries rely on that change between different instantiations of Jira.
# Please provide a string name reference to your instance's IssueType for
# the lowest level of Issues (e.g., "user story") specific to your Jira
# instance.  Note:  You can retrieve your instance's IssueType Name
# listings via the following URI:  https://[your-jira-domain-name]/rest/api/2/issuetype/
#############################################################################
feature.jiraIssueTypeId=Story

#############################################################################
# In Jira, your instance will have its own custom field created for "sprint" or "timebox" details,
# which includes a list of information.  This field allows you to specify that data field for your
# instance of Jira. Note: You can retrieve your instance's sprint data field name
# via the following URI, and look for a package name com.atlassian.greenhopper.service.sprint.Sprint;
# your custom field name describes the values in this field:

#############################################################################
feature.jiraSprintDataFieldName=customfield_10000

#############################################################################
# In Jira, your instance will have its own custom field created for "super story" or "epic" back-end ID,
# which includes a list of information.  This field allows you to specify that data field for your instance
# of Jira.  Note:  You can retrieve your instance's epic ID field name via the following URI where your
# queried user story issue has a super issue (e.g., epic) tied to it; your custom field name describes the
# epic value you expect to see, and is the only field that does this for a given issue:
# https://[your-jira-domain-name]/rest/api/2/issue/[some-issue-name]
#############################################################################
feature.jiraEpicIdFieldName=

#

#############################################################################
feature.todoStatuses[0]=To Do
feature.doingStatuses[0]=In Progress
feature.doneStatuses[0]=Done

#############################################################################
# In Jira, general IssueType IDs are associated to various 'issue'
# attributes. However, there is one attribute which this collector's
# queries rely on that change between different instantiations of Jira.
# Please provide a string name reference to your instance's IssueType for
# the lowest level of Issues (for example, 'user story') specific to your Jira

# listings via the following URI:  https://[your-jira-domain-name]/rest/api/2/issuetype/

#############################################################################

feature.collectorItemOnlyUpdate=true

#Defines the maximum number of features allow per board. If limit is reach collection will not happen for given board

feature.jiraBoardAsTeam=false

column2:
Problem: When attempting to rehome to a new MongoDB, it fails to authenticate. Sniffer capture shows it is not using the `admin` DB in Mongo to authenticate, rather it is trying to auth against the DB where Hygieia will be storing its data.

Relevant log excerpt:
```
[{address=REDACTED:27021, type=UNKNOWN, state=CONNECTING, exception={com.mongodb.MongoSecurityException: Exception authenticating MongoCredential{mechanism=SCRAM-SHA-1, userName='REDACTED', source='REDACTED_DB_NAME', password=<hidden>, mechanismProperties={}}}, caused by {com.mongodb.MongoCommandException: Command failed with error 18: 'Authentication failed.' on server REDACTED:27021. The full response is { "ok" : 0.0, "errmsg" : "Authentication failed.", "code" : 18, "codeName" : "AuthenticationFailed", 
```

... where `REDACTED_DB_NAME` is the name of the DB that Hygieia will store its data, should it be able to auth... which is the same DB I see in the sniffer caps it is trying to perform initial auth to, instead of `admin`.

I have connected to the same Mongo cluster with the same creds - though using the `admin` DB to auth, of course - and it works fine.

I did try changing some of the Spring Boot config relevant to this (e.g.: `spring.data.mongodb.authentication-database=admin`), but no joy.

Is there something I'm missing here, or is the code hardwired to assume that the user lives in Hygieia's DB, instead of `admin`?
column5: Unable to get services to auth against "admin" DB in Mongo; uses Hygieia's DB, instead

	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748) [na:1.8.0_201]
```

It looks to me like it is getting a NullPointer when trying to read the username, but I am including it in the config file:

```
# Database Name
dbname=dashboarddb

# Database HostName - default is localhost
dbhost=my.db.ip.address

# Database Port - default is 27017
dbport=27017

# Database Username - default is blank
dbusername=dashboarduser

# Database Password - default is blank
dbpassword=dbpassword

# Collector schedule (required)
nexusiq.cron=0 0/5 * * * *

# Nexus IQ server(s) (required) - Can provide multiple
nexusiq.servers[0]=https://my.nexus.iq.url

# Nexus IQ username/password - with read-access to all reports, and so on.
nexusiq.username=myUsername
nexusiq.password=myPassword

logging.level.com.capitalone.dashboard.collector=DEBUG

#In case of multiple license violations for a given library, consider the strictest violation
nexusiq.selectStricterLicense=true
```

(I have replaced my urls, credentials, ips, etc. with placeholder values).

It looks like it is finding my properties file, as my NexusIQ url is correctly loaded, but it does not seem to be able to find the username for some reason. Am I configuring something incorrectly, or is there an issue with how the properties file is loaded in the collector?
column5: Nexus IQ Collector: NullPointerException Getting Username

Configured application.properties as per the document - 

`
# Database Name
dbname=dashboarddb

# Database HostName - default is localhost
dbhost=127.0.0.1

# Database Port - default is 27017
dbport=27017

# MongoDB replicaset
dbreplicaset=false
dbhostport=127.0.0.1:27017

# Database Username - default is blank
dbusername=

# Database Password - default is blank
dbpassword=

# Collector schedule (required)
git.cron=0 0/1 * * * *

# Mandatory parameters
git.host=http://scm.******.com:<port>
git.api=/rest/api/1.0/

# Maximum number of days to go back in time when fetching commits
git.commitThresholdDays=15

# Page size for rest calls
#   Only applicable to Bitbucket Server.
#   Only applicable to Bitbucket Cloud.
git.pageSize=25

# Bitbucket product
#   Set to 'cloud' to use Bitbucket Cloud (formerly known as Bitbucket)
#   Set to 'server' to use Bitbucket Server (formerly known as Stash)
#   More information can be found here:
#   https://github.com/capitalone/Hygieia/issues/609
git.product=server

logging.level.com.capitalone.dashboard=INFO
logging.level.com.capitalone.dashboard.collector=INFO

column2:
Hi, We are looking for a custom collector that would fetch the data from Pivotal Cloud Foundry. Our requirement is to use the API endpoints similar to below to fetch details like  Version of application in each environment, status of services, application health, listener status, etc

1. Application version in each environment
API endpoint - http://<pcf-environment-url>/<application-name>/cloudfoundryapplication/info
RESPONSE - {"eureka":{"instance":{"metadata-map":{"user":{"password":"${eureka.instance.metadata-map.user.password}","name":"${eureka.instance.metadata-map.user.name}"}}},"UCD_Deployed_Version":"myApp-114"}}}

2. Application Health
API ENDPOINT - http://<pcf-environment-url>/<application-name>/cloudfoundryapplication/health 
RESPONSE - "hystrix":{"status":"UP"},"redis":{"status":"UP","details":{"version":"4.0.8"}}

3. Listener Status
API ENDPOINT - http://<pcf-environment-url>/<application-name>/admin/listenerStatus
RESPONSE - {"success":true,"messages":[],"responseBody":"['Listener': 'container', 'Active': 'true', 'Running': 'true', 'Active Consumers': '10']"}

Please let us know if this is feasible and any pointers to start with the custom collector. This would help us to monitor the applications closely on Hygieia dashboard. I appreciate any kind of help on this.
Thanks.
column5: Custom collector to fetch data from Pivotal Cloud Foundry

column2: When an error is thrown for a GraphQL query, the errors are returned in the JSON response.  The errors are checked for "NOT_FOUND", which means that the repo could have been redirected.  A REST call is made to the original repo to look for the new repo url.
column5: Graphql collector fix for redirected repos

column2:
Will look for repo renames, and repo transfers to another org.  Works if there are multiple redirects, all of the redirected repos will point to the last repo.

If the error in the graphQL query is "NOT_FOUND", then it will make a REST call to the original repo to find out if it was redirected.

column2:
Hi Team,
i am trying to create a docker image and deploy in cloud as a POC , hence i am looking for a way to test the dashboard locally once i deploy the docker image.
we have this command to test locally --> gulp serve --local true
but for docker we will be executing the command --> docker run -t -p 8088:80 --link hygieia-api -i hygieia-ui:latest

can anyone please let me know how to use test data for UI when API/UI/DB are containerized.

Regards,
vishal
column5: how to test UI locally for docker

column2:
facing some issues while trying to get the udeploy collector integrated with the dashboard.I am able to see the apps being pulled from udeploy in the logs but the same isn't reflecting in the widget on the dashboard.

We already have a working setup for Jenkins where we are able to view the builds on the build widget but we are facing issues while trying to get that working for udeploy and Bitbucket(public repo)


[udeploy_prop.txt](https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/files/3013341/udeploy_prop.txt)
[udeploy-collector.log](https://github.com/Hygieia/Hygieia/files/3013335/udeploy-collector.log)

column2:
I have made changes to feature model in hygieia core to add priority and severity fields. Build of Hygieia core is successful. SNAPSHOT of core jar got created.

While compiling feature-collector new attributes of feature model is not resolved and compilation error is thrown.
column5: hygieia core model change is not considered in feature collector build

column2: I was having issues with getting all the different story types with the only one story id from my companies jira instance. So I added the capability for multiple story ids.
column5: Jira: Add in capability for multiple story ids

column2:
Hi
I am trying to publish Jacoco Coverage trend published via Jenkins build on my Hygieia: Code Quality widget.
In Jenkins my Jacoco Code Coverage shows data:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24870997/54532175-27f44300-49ad-11e9-9bbc-1c1bdd8b3522.png)

But is inconsistant with Hygieia: Jenkins-codequality module.

The JSON object I get from Jenkins for code quality is like: 
{"branchCoverage":{"covered":0,"missed":44815,"percentage":0,"percentageFloat":0.0,"total":44815},"classCoverage":{"covered":3,"missed":109,"percentage":3,"percentageFloat":2.6785715,"total":112},"complexityScore":{"covered":13,"missed":24606,"percentage":0,"percentageFloat":0.052804746,"total":24619},"instructionCoverage":{"covered":61,"missed":378392,"percentage":0,"percentageFloat":0.01611825,"total":378453},"lineCoverage":{"covered":27,"missed":68241,"percentage":0,"percentageFloat":0.03955001,"total":68268},"methodCoverage":{"covered":13,"missed":2197,"percentage":1,"percentageFloat":0.5882353,"total":2210}}

Please suggest is it possible to integrate Jenkins jacoco code coverage report with existing Hygieia Code Quality widget 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24870997/54532511-ec0dad80-49ad-11e9-9dac-6b83aaff3226.png)

or I have to create a new collector altogether to display this data.

 Thanks in advance
column5: Hygieia: Configuring Code Analysis widget with Jacoco Coverage report
